term.description: The application of a word to an object it does not literary denote in order to suggest comparison with another object.
term.context: She is a real flower.

term.description: Metaphors so frequently employed that they have lost any expressive power.
term.context: Ruby lips, hair of gold, snow-white skin.

term.description: A statement that requires thinking over a confusing or difficult problem that needs to be solved.
term.context: How many blocks of stone did it take to complete one of the pyramids?

term.description: The mention of a part for the whole.
term.context: A fleet of 50 sail.

term.description: Substitution of one word for another on the basis of real connection.
term.context: Crown – sovereign

term.description: Misuse of a word due to the false folk etymology or wrong application of a term in a sense that does not belong to the word. This sort of misuse is mostly based on similarity in sound.
term.context: Disinterested (бескорыстный) – uninterested

term.description: A word or phrase used to describe someone or something with a purpose to praise or blame.
term.context: It was a lovely, summery evening.

term.description: Putting things in a round about way in order to bring out some important feature or explain more clearly the idea or situation described.
term.context: I got an Arab boy… and paid him twenty rupees a month, about thirty bob…

term.description: Use of exaggerated terms for emphasis.
term.context: A thousand apologies

term.description: Use of a proper name to express a general idea or conversely a common name for a proper one.
term.context: The Iron Lady

term.description: Use of several conjunctions
term.context: He thought, and thought, and thought…

term.description: Repetition of a word at the beginning clauses, sentences, verses
term.context: No tree, no shrub, no blade of grass…

term.description: Running on of one thought into the next line, couplet or stanza without breaking the syntactical pattern.
term.context: “A thing of beauty is a joy forever: Its loveliness increases; it will never Pass into nothingness but still will keep…”

term.description: Omission of conjunction
term.context: “Consciousness of place came ebbing back to him slowly over a vast tract of time unlit, unfelt, unlived…..”

term.description: Some part of speech relating to one noun is referred to another
term.context: He lost his hart and his temper

term.description: A reversal in the order of words in one of two parallel phrases
term.context: He went to the country, to the town went she.

term.description: Omission of words needed to complete the construction of the sense
term.context: Tomorrow at 1:30

term.description: Choice or arrangement of words that emphasises a contrast
term.context: Give me liberty or give me death

term.description: The upsetting for effect of the normal order of the words (or just inversion)
term.context: Me he restored, him he hanged.

term.description: Direct and indirect
term.context: Ding-dong, tinkle

term.description: Initial rhyme
term.context: To rob Peter to pay Paul

term.description: A repetition of similar sounds (or the same sound) in two or more words, most often in the final syllables of lines in poems and songs.
term.context: Baa baa black sheep, have you any wool? Yes sir, yes sir, three bags full!

term.description: Literary device which demonstrates the long and short patterns through stressed and unstressed syllables particularly in verse form.
term.context: Shall I compare thee to a summer’s day? _U _U _U _U _U

term.description: Words are used in such a way that their intended meaning is different from the actual meaning of the words.
term.context: The butter is as soft as a marble piece.

term.description: The association of one word with two or more distinct meanings
term.context: “Just do it” (Nike’s slogan)

term.description: A play on words in which a humorous effect is produced by using a word that suggests two or more meanings or by exploiting similar sounding words having different meanings.
term.context: We will dye for you (a slogan of clothes colouring company)

term.description: The use of a proper name in place of a common one or vice versa to emphasize some feature or quality
term.context: Mr. Facing-Both-Ways does not very fear in this world.

term.description: A comparison, showing similarities between two different things.
The use of excessive and longer words to convey a meaning which could have been conveyed with a shorter expression or in a few words.
term.context: The fair sex - women

term.description: Polite, indirect expressions which replace words and phrases considered harsh and impolite or which suggest something unpleasant.
term.context: To go to heaven – to die

term.description: Exaggeration of ideas for the sake of emphasis.
term.context: The Earth was made for Dombey and son to trade…

term.description: An expression that has been overused to the extent that it loses its original meaning or novelty.
term.context: Crushing defeat

term.description: A brief, simple and popular saying, or a phrase that gives advice and effectively embodies a commonplace truth based on practical experience or common sense.
term.context: He said, milk’s spilt.

term.description: A memorable, brief, interesting and surprising satirical statement.
term.context: A thing of beauty is joy for ever. (Ketas)

term.description: The repetition of one expression as part of another one
term.context: Ecclesiastes said, “that all is vanity”.

term.description: A brief and indirect reference to a person, place, thing or idea of historical, cultural, literary or political significance.
term.context: Don’t act like Romeo in front of her!

term.description: Set phrase - a phrase whose parts are fixed in a certain order, even if the phrase could be changed without harming the literal meaning.
term.context: You know which side the law’s buttered.

term.description: A reversal of normal order of words in a sentence
term.context: A tone of most extravagant comparison Miss Tox said it in.

term.description: A seemingly independent part of a sentence carries some additional information
term.context: She was lovely: all of her – delightful.

term.description: The use of identical or similar parallel syntactical structure in two or more sentences or their parts
term.context: The seeds ye sow — another reaps, The robes ye weave—another wears, The arms ye forge—another bears.

term.description: Inversion of the second of two parallel constructions
term.context: In the days of old men made manners, manners now make men (Byron)

term.description: Homogenous parts of a sentence are made semantically heterogeneous.
term.context: The principal production of these towns… appear to be soldiers, sailors, Jews, chalk, shrimps, officers, and dock-yard-men.

term.description: Withholding the most important information or idea till the end of a sentence, paragraph, text.
term.context: Know ye the land where the cypress and myrtle

term.description: A rhetorical series of ideas, images arranged progressively so that the most forceful is last
term.context: They looked at hundred of houses, they climbed thousands of stars, they inspected innumerable kitchens. (Maugham)

term.description: Opposition of ideas in the parts of a sentence/different sentences.
term.context: Youth is lovely – age is lonely; youth is fiery – age is frost. (Longfellow)

term.description: The omission of conjunctions
term.context: Soams turned away; he had an utter disinclination for talk, like one standing before an open grave… (Galsworthy)

term.description: The use of a number of conjunctions in close session
term.context: The heaviest rain, and snow, and hail, and sleet, could boast of the advantage over him in only one respect. (Dickens)

term.description: Seemingly incoherent connection of two sentences based on an unexpected semantic leap
term.context: It was an afternoon to dream. And she took out John’s letters. (Galsworthy)

term.description: All sorts of omission in a sentence.
term.context: Nothing so difficult as a beginning; how soft the chin which bears his touch. (Byron)

term.description: A sudden breaking off in the midst of a sentence as if from inability or unwillingness to proceed
term.context: Good intentions but -; You just come home or I’ll…

term.description: Is that form of utterance which conveys the actual words of the speaker through the mouth of the writer but retains the peculiarities of the speaker's mode of expression.
term.context: Over and over he asked himself: would she receive him?

term.description: A figure of speech in the form of a question that is asked in order to make a point rather than to elicit an answer.
term.context: How long must we suffer? Where is the end? (Norris)

term.description: Understatement for effect, esp. that in which an affirmative is expressed by negation of the contrary.
term.context: He was no gentle lamb (London)
